Title:
Additions to the knowledge of corticioid Xylodon
(Schizoporaceae, Hymenochaetales): introducing three new Xylodon species
from the southern China
Keywords:
Biodiversity; Molecular systematics; Taxonomy; White rot
fungi; Wood-decaying fungi; Yunnan Province
Abstract:
The corticioid fungi play crucial roles as decomposers in
forest ecosystems, and three new corticioid fungi, Xylodon gossypinus,
X. macrosporus and X. sinensis spp. nov. are here proposed based on a
combination of morphological features and molecular evidence. Xylodon
gossypinus is characterized by the resupinate basidiomata with cotton
hymenophore, presence of cystidia with three types, and ellipsoid
basidiospores; X. macrosporus is characterized by resupinate basidiomata
with cracking hymenophore with pale yellowish hymenial surface, and
larger basidiospores 810.5 × 7.59 µm); X. sinensis differs by its
grandinioid hymenial surface and subglobose basidiospores measuring as
35 × 2.54 µm. Sequences of ITS and nLSU rRNA markers of the studied
samples were generated, and phylogenetic analyses were performed with
maximum likelihood, maximum parsimony, and Bayesian inference methods.
The ITS+nLSU analysis in Hymenochaetales revealed that the three new
species clustered into family Schizoporaceae, located in genus Xylodon;
based on the ITS dataset, X. gossypinus was sister to X. borealis; X.
macrosporus closely grouped with X. follis with a high supports; X.
sinensis retrieved as a sister to X. rimosissimus with a lower
supports.
